body:
So I guess we should flag addresses depending on how we find them.
If we got the address via local discovery, we should return an extra flag part of the address which would tell us not to wrap the connection in a limiter.

But then a manual given IP should still be limited or not? 

e.g. 192.168.0.5:22000,dynamic

Well `dynamic` means use all possible discovery clients.
Currently they just return a bunch of addresses, regardless if they are local or global.
We should basically start flagging addresses as global or local (depending on which client discovered the IP) and then wrap the socket in a limiter or not.

Doing it on a subnet basis is no good, as I have `44.44.44.0/24` as my LAN address space.

@AudriusButkevicius Doing this based on which way we discovered a devices seems to be the smart option. If we think about the future IPv6 will mean many more devices without NAT, even tough it does have a local address range.

I'd love to see this feature because the current design chokes ST to death on local networks and breaks the idea of having one storage pod per physical location for fast local file exchange.

Surely if you remove the limits it should perform exactly the same as over WAN?
I think you are referring to stripping of encryption for LAN? Which I believe was closed as won't fix, as we cannot identify a friendly lan vs hostile lan in a public airport/internet cafe

Sorry, bad wording. I meant that if the local transfer speed is limited (choked) to the same speed as the WAN connections, there isn't really a speed bonus for having a local node which is always on.

I currently have four locations with 2-5 Syncthing devices each plus one "stupid storage node", but right now I can only choose between throttling all upload and none.
While the first option means very slow sync on the LAN, the second one means unhappy family/friends, because their upload bandwidth is completely blocked, meaning calls that "the internet is slow".

I'd never ask to strip encryption anywhere, no worries ;-)

With this I just wanted to underline that it would be very much appreciated if there were a button to ignore the bandwidth limit on local connections. A second set of up/down bandwidths for local connections would probably be too confusing to the average user.
Yeah, it's not rocket science to implement, but someone has to invest the half an hour to do that.

generalmanager: What about set bandwidth control in router? I have this set up, every computer in my networks use some amount of capacity to internet and everything they can to each other and therefore i'm not using this feature in syncthing. But i still think it is desirable feature and i would even combine this 2 aproaches, so that user could set up limits to both (LAN, internet) and then use a button in device settings to tell syncthing "use LAN limits", which would also eliminate problems with decision whether device is connected via LAN or net.

@chucic I have BW priorization set up correctly, but even with this http traffic is down to a crawl. Which is an improvement, because before the connections would timeout, but still.

This is also not a solution for most users, because they have no idea this might exist (many routers don't support it) or ever logged into their router. And they don't call it router, it's the little box where all the cables go (not the one for electricity).

Thus I'd like the Syncthing setting to be as useful as possible. 

Regarding your proposal: I think we should try to keep  the UI clutter as low as possible, thus this should only be shown if the user entered an address manually. In this case there was no discovery service involved and we can't classify the device in any other way. But most users will use local and global discovery - they don't need to see this all the time.

And in times where laptops have a bigger marketshare than traditional PCs, it's often not possible any more to define a device as strictly accessible via a local network. 

I think it can solve an edge case for which the method proposed by @AudriusButkevicius doesn't work, but shouldn't get in the way as long as it's not needed.

I think this should just have a single checkbox "Apply bandwidth throttling in local area network" (unchecked by default), and only classify an IP as local if it was discovered via {broad,multi}casts. 

If you manually provided an IP, I guess we should still assume it's WAN.

Unless someone wants to go the extra mile checking IPs+subnets local to the machine and verifying if the IP in question is in our subnet. In which case we don't even need to classify how the machine was discovered... we just check whether or not it's within our subnet.

Half of the work already done by someone:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23529663/how-to-get-all-addresses-and-masks-from-local-interfaces-in-go

This has interesting implications for VPNs (OpenVPN, Hamachi, tinc, etc.) which will inherently look like LANs at this level (that's the whole point, after all).  Also related to #1305 and #219.

(Not complaining -- I love the feature; just wanted to point out one of the implications of it for future travellers. :+1:)
It has a toggle switch in the config.

Yeah, I saw. :smile: :+1:  Just wanted to point out what should be obvious, but also include some key terms here for folks searching for VPN (that they probabaly want to either turn this off or manage their VPNs differently via separate `syncthing` instances, etc).

I really like this functionality. Do you think there is a chance for this to get a checkbox in the web UI? 
I'd imagine this kind of feature would be useful for many users who are not comfortable with digging around in config files.
And if one doesn't know a feature like this exists, most users wouldn't think to search for it in the documentation.
You wouldn't even need to make the settings menu bigger, just put the fields for in/outgoing limits in one line and add the checkbox below.
